awd_titl_txt: SaTC: EDU: Collaborative: Advancing Cybersecurity Learning Through Inquiry-based Laboratories on a Container-based Virtualization Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
It is critical to educate and train a cybersecurity-capable workforce in an era where security breaches, privacy violations, and phishing scams have become commonplace. However, due to the complicated and abstract nature of many cybersecurity concepts and techniques, it is challenging for students to comprehend them in an effective manner. To address this challenge, this project seeks to create innovative learning materials and tools that can help transform the status quo of cybersecurity education. The project design is based on the inquiry-based learning model and enabled by recent advances in virtualization technology. Specifically, this project consists of a set of inquiry-based, hands-on laboratories that are hosted on an affordable, scalable, extensible, and low-maintenance container-based virtualization platform. This project meets the pressing and essential needs in cybersecurity curricula by aiding the development of new lab materials and courses for community and four-year colleges. 

In this project, three types of hands-on labs will be designed and developed: Outreach, Core, and Advanced. Outreach labs are designed specifically for community college students to inspire their curiosity and interest in cybersecurity, and thus, to drive them to continue their study in a 4-year college. The key purpose of the core labs is to assist the learning of complicated cybersecurity concepts and technologies. The advanced labs aim at not only introducing emerging security technologies, but also inspiring students who are interested in doing research in these areas. All of our lab materials and software tools will be open-source and available to learners, educators, and researchers. Lastly, training on the container-based cloud computing platform will be offered to instructors and graduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In order to address the ever-growing prevalence of cyber-attacks, privacy breaches, and data vulnerabilities in our rapidly evolving world, it has become imperative to empower the future workforce with extensive knowledge and practical skills in the field of computer and network security. With the constantly evolving landscape of cyber threats and hackers continuously developing sophisticated techniques to exploit vulnerabilities in our cyber-physical systems, our project endeavors to create a lasting impact on cybersecurity education by offering learners captivating and challenging hands-on learning materials, such as labs. By equipping the future workforce with the necessary knowledge and skills, we aim to fortify the cybersecurity defenses of individuals, organizations, and society as a whole, contributing to a safer and more secure digital ecosystem. 


In this project, we have developed a series of hands-on cybersecurity labs that encompass a wide array of topics, ranging from password safety and scalable Kerberos authentication to ransomware, blockchain technology, smart contracts, database security, protocol security (such as TLS and SSH), intrusion detection and prevention, web security, etc. For each lab, we provided detailed instructions and reference materials. In addition, we have developed a generic lab environment (based on Docker) for carrying our developed labs, which provides a consistent workflow, logical operations, simplicity, and good usability. Lastly, we have developed a lab publishing and usage analysis platform. The platform is fully functional and is available at https://eurekalabs.net/. 


The project provides many valuable resources for understanding cybersecurity threats/attacks and practicing defense mechanisms. The developed labs have been adopted in various security-related courses in numerous colleges in the United States and other countries. In the past 24 months (from 07/01/2021 to 06/30/2023), we have published 16 hands-on labs and each one averages about 2,000 views/downloads in this 24-month period, with the total number of views/downloads exceeding 32,000. We have about 2,100 new visitors/users from 118 countries, with about 39% from the United States. We are confident that this fully functional platform will provide educators and students with a powerful tool to enhance their teaching and learning experiences. Many results have been published in top-notched journals and conferences including IEEE Communications Magazine, IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing, IEEE Transactions on Communications, IEEE Internet of Things Journal, IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics, ACM Transactions on Knowledge Discovery from Data, IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems, and Society for Information Technology & Teacher Education International Conference, etc. We have also presented our developed labs to local community colleges and high school students to increase their awareness of cyber threats and defense mechanisms.


The outcomes of this research carry profound implications for cybersecurity education and training, reaching far beyond the confines of the project itself. The meticulously designed learning materials aim to be inclusive, relevant, and cost-effective, ensuring accessibility for learners from diverse backgrounds. These resources have not only been successfully employed within the researchers' respective institutions but have also made a significant impact on a broader audience of learners. By integrating cutting-edge technologies into the learning process, our labs have sparked a profound interest and enthusiasm among students, motivating them to pursue further research in cybersecurity fields. Notably, several PhD students, partially supported by this project, have successfully completed their dissertations and become tenure-track Assistant Professors after graduation. Additionally, a number of undergraduate students from underrepresented groups have been inspired to pursue graduate studies, further advancing their research endeavors in the realm of cybersecurity.

Modified by: Liran Ma
